headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the FIS Fourth Quarter Year-End 2015 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now like to turn the conference over to
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the FIS Fourth Quarter Year-End 2015 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Pete Gunnlaugsson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Turning to Slide 2. Gary Norcross, President and Chief Executive Officer, will begin with a business summary. Woody Woodall, Chief Fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Turning to Slide 2. Gary Norcross, President and Chief Executive Officer, will begin with a business summary. Woody Woodall, Chief Financial Officer, will continue with the financial results for the quarter and the full year. Today's news release and the supplemental slide presentation are available on our website at fisglobal.com.
Turning to Slide 3. Today's remarks will contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties as described in the press release and other filings with the SEC. The company undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by law. Please refer to the safe harbor language.
Today's remarks will also include references to non-GAAP financial measures in order to provide more meaningful comparisons between the periods presented. These non-GAAP measures are outlined on Slide 3 as well. Reconciliations between the GAAP and non-GAAP results are provided in the attachments to the press release and in the appendix of the supplemental slide presentation.
Turning to Slide 4, I will turn the call over to Gary to discuss the business highlights. Gary?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on today's call. I'm pleased to report we exited 2015 with solid momentum as the team is focused on execution and driving further improvements in our cost structure and overall performa
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on today's call. I'm pleased to report we exited 2015 with solid momentum as the team is focused on execution and driving further improvements in our cost structure and overall performance, delivering continued earnings growth. We're in the right markets empowering our clients of all sizes, whether here in the U.S. with community and regional banks or globally. Our long-term strategy has consistently driven year-over-year performance results, and we remain committed to our strategy. 
Turning to Slide 5. We continue to build global scale in 2015, finalizing our acquisitions of SunGard and finishing the year with revenue increasing 7% on a constant currency basis to $6.6 billion, growing adjusted EBITDA 8% on a constant currency basis to $2 billion and producing adjusted earnings per share of 6% on a constant currency basis to $3.22. We generated $921 million free cash flow and returned $605 million to shareholders. Strategically, we are investing in the business to deliver long-term growth and superior shareholder returns. We are entering 2016 focused on 3 growth drivers. First, the acquisition of SunGard broadens our solution portfolio, allowing us to expand into new and adjacent markets and provide deeper value to our clients. Second, we will continue to capitalize on our expanded skill, operating leverage and a disciplined integration to drive earnings growth. Third, our strong cash flow generation allows us to invest for growth and return capital to shareholders. 
Turning to Slide 6. Our SunGard acquisition, which closed on November 30, is a meaningful value creator for FIS. As we have discussed in the past, the industry is continuing to move towards fewer providers due to the complexity of solutions and regulatory oversight. As a result, our strategy has been to continue to expand our broad array of IP-led products built for the financial services industry, augmented with the right transformation services components needed to bridge the gap between these complex systems in the new digital age. The SunGard acquisition is another key component in implementing these overall strategy. In addition to opening complimentary new markets, this combination positively impacts our revenue mix, creating a more profitable product-centric revenue base in the ability to accelerate margin expansion by implementing our leading go-to-market delivery approach as well as significant cost savings around administration and technology expenses. This acquisition expands beyond our traditional retail banking and payments footprint into the institutional and wholesale side of the financial solutions as well as other buy-side organizations. On a combined basis, our share of wallet with our common global clients increased dramatically due to these combination, allowing us to become a more strategic solution provider. This comment has been substantiated multiple times over the last 60 days as we've engaged with many of our global question regarding the combination. The benefits of the transaction do not stop with our global banks. It also significantly expands our existing solutions and client base in wealth management, treasury and corporate payments. These are in high demand among our regional and community institutions and has been a significant focus area for FIS as our clients look for ways to replace their fee revenue due to continuing regulatory changes and increased oversight. As we look at the December results for SunGard, we are pleased with the momentum the sales organization maintained throughout the month and are also pleased with the health of the overall pipeline that we acquired. While still early, we're also excited about how the sales teams are collaborating and building further opportunities within our robust clients set which further substantiates the strategy on why we put these 2 companies together. Finally, this transaction brings very strong talent in increased leadership to FIS with market-specific expertise. This further positions FIS as the clear leader in financial technology globally, strengthening our ability to deliver for our clients and help them grow their business. 
Turning to Slide 7. Based on the significant strategic rationale discussed, the overall alignment has been equally strong given both companies' DNA is centered on development products for financial services. This cultural alignment allowed us to accelerate our integration efforts, and we are very pleased with our initial progress integrating these 2 great companies. For example, have already rolled out a streamlined organizational structure, transitioned our North American payroll and benefits plans and completed the rollout of the rebranding of SunGard. Given our current pace and results to date, we are ahead to exit 2016 at our synergy run rate goal of $100 million and are confident in our ability to exit 2017 with the synergy run rate of $200 million. FIS has a proven track record of meeting or exceeding our synergy targets. And based on progress to date, this record will continue. While that wraps up my comments regarding the strategy and integration of SunGard, the company had other notable successes in support of our growth. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing some of these key results. 
Turn to Slide 8 to review the segment highlights. Our Integrated Financial Solutions business continue to cross-sell and upsell additional products and services through our North American client base, leveraging the strength of our portfolio. In particular, we saw a continued demand for our digital solutions, well and -- production and institutions of all sizes. In addition, the expanded our relationship with large online retailer in the fourth quarter, resulting in double-digit growth in our high-margin network services business. Our mobile business continues its industry-leading position, growing its number of registered users by 19% year-over-year and delivering 27% year-over-year growth in our hosted service model. Overall, our digital finance withdrew -- greater than $250 million in revenue at margins greater than 40%. Card production increased 12% to 112 million cards in closing of a much driving EMV. EMV grew sequentially 15% from Q3 to Q4 in 2015 resulting in full year production of 12.5 million EMV cards. We continue to build traction among mid-tier community institutions, signing several new long-term core process and partnerships in the quarter and for your. The success we saw in core processing signings for the year was almost double the number of deals in 2014. These wins in 2015 create positive benefits for 2016 and beyond. Also in the quarter, we signed the bank with assets greater than $200 billion to consolidate its debit processing and associated fraud-related services. The decision was driven by the banks' desire to improve operating efficiencies and increase service flexibility with a common solution across its expansive retail and direct bank business. This significant multiyear agreement demonstrates FIS' strength in serving the payments needs of institutions of all sizes around the world. 2015 was the transition year for Global Financial Solutions business. We responded to the challenges presented to us in the year whether they were due to global economic issues, overall softness in market demand for people-based services or execution. We made leadership changes to address execution issues and refocus the impacted businesses. Regarding our consulting business, Capco, we're seeing progress in building our pipeline for consultative deals but continue to expect a slow recovery in the first half of 2016 with increased performance in the back half of the year. As we discussed in the strategic rationale for SunGard, our non-product lead business is now make up less than 10% of our total revenue. Globally, our Clear2Pay business showed very strong momentum, growing over 20% for the full year fueled by solid demand for real-time payments and clear competitive differentiation in this space. We acquired Clear2Pay in 2014, with the strategic view of the market direction and is another illustration of how discipline acquisitions and careful integration can enhance our client value proposition in earnings growth profile. During the quarter, our GFS segment signed a bank in North America with assets greater than $100 billion to a new multiyear agreement for a new direct bank, providing an end-to-end integrated solution for core banking, fraud solutions, back office and call center services. This key win underscores our ability to deliver innovative technology solutions that empower our clients to better serve customers in today's digital age. In Brazil, we were encouraged to see 1 of our key clients pursue the purchase of a large card portfolio expanding their franchise for future growth even in a difficult macroeconomic environment. This acquisition expands our ongoing business in Brazil, and we are already seeing the benefit of revenue stream as we provide professional services expertise to on-board these accounts in the back half of the year. In Europe, we continue to show positive sales momentum, especially in the U.K. and Germany, where we saw important wins across the year that will fuel continued growth in 2016. Our strategy within the region is building momentum around over expand the relationships by leveraging existing strengths within the FIS and SunGard portfolios. We are making strong progress in the sincere engagement. We have recently delivered the new platform which is a key milestone in the project. Testing is underway and we now plan to migrate customers on to the new platform later this year. We are proud of our partnership with this client, and we look forward to empowering them as our strategic technology partner over the next decade. We also signed the first all-digital bank in the U.K. as we help this client prepare for their upcoming loans in 2016. Asia continued to have a strong growth throughout 2015. And we are pleased at the SunGard acquisition more than doubles our sales force in the region, which allows us to continue to address the demand for FIS products and services throughout the high-growth region. 
Turning next to Slide 9. Before I turn the call over to Woody for the financial review, I'd like to summarize by emphasizing that our competitive positioning is strong, and our long-term earnings growth story remains intact. To meet our 2016 note growth and financial performance goals, we will continue to focus on driving profitable growth, maintaining a strong balance sheet, returning cash to shareholders and continued acceleration of our integration efforts. With that, I'd like to turn it over to Woody for additional detail on how the financial results for the quarter and full year. Woody?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. I'll begin with Slide 11 on the summary of our consolidated results for the quarter and then for the full year of 2015. The fourth quarter and full year results included the impact of the SunGard transaction, which closed on November 30. Tho
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. I'll begin with Slide 11 on the summary of our consolidated results for the quarter and then for the full year of 2015. The fourth quarter and full year results included the impact of the SunGard transaction, which closed on November 30. Those results are reported in the GFS segment. Today, unless otherwise specified, I'll be referencing percentage changes in our metrics on a constant currency basis. Also, reconciliations of non-GAAP measures can be found in our press release and our earnings deck, which is posted on the Investor Relations page of our website. In the fourth quarter, revenue increased $1.9 billion or 18% and adjusted EBITDA increased 21% to $624 million. Adjusted net earnings from continuing operations increased 13% to $278 million, and adjusted earnings per share was $0.93. In the quarter, foreign currency translation negatively impacted revenue by $63 million, EBITDA by $12 million and earnings per share by $0.02. For the year, revenue increased 7% to $6.6 billion and adjusted EBITDA increased 8% to $2 billion. Adjusted net earnings from continuing operations increased $930 million, a 6% increase; and adjusted earnings per share was $3.22. For the year, foreign currency translation negatively impacted revenue by $243 million, EBITDA about $45 million and earnings per share about $0.07. 
I will now continue on Slide 12 for segment results. In the fourth quarter, Integrated Financial Solutions revenue grew 4.4% on a normalized basis to $1 billion. EBITDA was 3% -- EBITDA increased 3% to $405 million compared to the prior-year period. We are pleased with the results of the segment and the underlying business continues to perform well. For the year, IFS revenue on a normalized basis increased 3% to $3.9 billion, and EBITDA increased 2% to $1.6 billion. 
Turning to Slide 13. Our IFS growth was driven by digital and risk solutions and by increase in EMV card production volumes. Regarding revenue composition remains very high in IFS. 
Turning to Slide 14. In the fourth quarter, Global Financial Solutions revenue increased 38% to $902 million. SunGard contributed approximately $300 million of revenue and approximately $100 million of EBITDA. Excluding SunGard on a normalized basis, GFS revenue decreased 3%. This decrease was driven primarily by softness in professional services demand and a difficult comp to the prior-year period. GFS adjusted EBITDA increased to $259 million, representing a 58% increase. EBITDA growth in the quarter was driven by restructuring cost actions taken in the first half of the year and the inclusion of SunGard for 1 month. For the year, GFS revenue increased 16% to $2.7 billion. Excluding SunGard on a normalized basis, revenue grew 3%. EBITDA increased 25% to $629 million. 
Moving to Slide 15. We are presenting the results in the region including SunGard to give some player their regional impacts, although we know that SunGard's impact is on the for 1 month. Given that, my following commentary on the regions excludes SunGard and focuses on the GFS segment standalone performance. For the fourth quarter, North America decline approximately $50 million to $252 million. Almost half this decline was a result of the previously discussed contract nonrenewal followed by continued softness in professional service demand and a difficult license sale comparable in the prior-year period. For the year, North America revenues were $1.1 billion. As for the nonrenewal of the contract, full year revenue decreased 1% reflecting professional services softness in the second half of the year. In the quarter, Europe grew 1% to $198 million. For the year, Europe revenues increased 14% to $757 million. The fourth quarter results include the anniversary of our Clear2Pay acquisition and the impact of softness for people-based services in Europe. We are pleased about the results in Latin America and the contract expansion in Brazil is a nice win in the quarter and should help Latin America in 2016 in spite of difficult macroeconomic background. As Gary indicated earlier, we remain bullish on the long-term impact of the Asia Pacific region. The team has done a nice job of growing the business in this region. The addition of SunGard gives greater contribution from IP-led solutions, which we believe improves the visibility and predictability of results for this segment. 
Moving to Slide 16. For the quarter, free cash flow inquiries 12% to $399 million or 143% conversion of net earnings. And for the year, free cash flow increased 7% to $921 million or 99% conversion of net earnings. We are highly focused on paying down debt and deleveraging the balance sheet. The effective tax rate increased to 33.4% for the quarter compared to 32.6% in the prior-year period, driven by acquisition-related items. For the full year, the effective tax rate was 33.1%. 
Moving to Slide 17. In 2016 and going forward, we will report revenue growth on an organic basis. Organic revenue, excluding impact of acquisitions divestitures and foreign currency translation. We believe this will give better visibility in the underlying operating results of the business. For 2016, we expect organic revenue growth of 3% to 4%; adjusted EBITDA of $2.84 billion to $2.9 billion dollars; adjusted earnings per share of $3.70 to $3.80, representing growth of 15% to 18%. Free cash flow to approximate adjusted net earnings. As we think about the quarter-to-quarter flow of the operating plan, we generally expect 15% to 18% EPS growth each quarter and expect the impact of synergies and interest savings to increase over the course of the year. There is more information regarding our planning assumptions in the Appendix material, but I will highlight a handful of them here. We assumed net interest expense of approximately $370 million, in 2016 effective tax rate of approximately 35%. We believe that by implementing tax planning strategies over the next tax rate down by 200 basis points or more. Capital expenditures approximately 6% of revenue, reaffirming our goal of exiting 2016 with $100 million or more in run rate cost synergies. 
Moving to Slide 18. In conclusion, I'm highly confident in our operating plan and our ability to deliver double-digit earnings growth in 2016 and 2017. We remain focused on multiyear earnings growth and cash generation and believe our business model will create long-term shareholder value, and we continue to invest for growth and strive for leadership in the markets that we serve. That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, you may now open the line for questions.

In other words, what's embedded in the guidance for the full year? And then to the extent you have a target for calendar '17, that would also be helpful.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, again, we're targeting exiting targeting exiting $100 million or more. I will tell you for planning purposes, I would use the $100 million exit run rate. If you think about the flow of the operating plan, we'll try to give some color around 15% to
componenttext: David, again, we're targeting exiting targeting exiting $100 million or more. I will tell you for planning purposes, I would use the $100 million exit run rate. If you think about the flow of the operating plan, we'll try to give some color around 15% to 18% each quarter. If you think about how the synergies will flow, I would lean towards the 15% moving towards the 18% over the course of the year as the synergies come through and interest costs are reduced as we pay down debt. For 2017, David, we're still targeting $200 million exit run rate, and we would have that at least ratable at this point in time.

So we've gone through a number of already very significant milestones with the restructuring, the conversion of payroll and the other things we mention and just got line of sight into implementing the plans over the course of the year. So we're in really good shape on the integration comets gone very smoothly at this point.

componenttextpreview: That was my point I was trying to make in my prepared remarks. I was real pleased with the month of December in our SunGard execution. When I look they had every opportunity to really take their put off the gas. I mean, they could have gotten distractedly
componenttext: That was my point I was trying to make in my prepared remarks. I was real pleased with the month of December in our SunGard execution. When I look they had every opportunity to really take their put off the gas. I mean, they could have gotten distractedly the combination. We had a lot going on at the time. But things stay very focused through year-end and executed very well. So that was positive. When I look at the pipeline go into this year, the same thing exists. The pipelines are growing, the teams are executing. They're very excited about being a part of FIS, and I think that's relating into client base. I can't tell you why many comments I've got over the last 60 days from clients just talking about being up under FIS, our ability to invest in focus for the long-term. And to the customers are receiving it well. Our sales teams are receiving it well, and that's project into the results. So we feel really good about the. The secret is going to be as now since November 30, as we started to put our sales teams together and they started to have some conversations about joint selling into their account, we're also seeing some good traction there. Not only in the Global Financial Solutions but as I said, when you look at Treasury and wealth and many of the products at that SunGard had other applicable for regional and community banks, what you're seeing to see strong traction there as well. And then, of course, as you know, our consulting groups started in the capital markets area of the industry, and so being able to wrap that kind of consultant gave consultative engagement around products is going to be differentiating for us going forward.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

And then if you could give a little more color on Capco, you had mentioned I think toward the end of last year, you'd be taking over the business, repositioning it to focus more on high-end transformational consulting. What is the current growth for Capco? And what do you think it could be exiting '16?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw mid-single digit growth for Capco last year, which was obviously substantially less than what has being done in the prior year years. As you mentioned, Lance is taking over the helm of the consulting group. We've really rallied the partners ar
componenttext: Yes, we saw mid-single digit growth for Capco last year, which was obviously substantially less than what has being done in the prior year years. As you mentioned, Lance is taking over the helm of the consulting group. We've really rallied the partners around, engaging more into the transformational consulting side, which tries a higher margin and also more complementary to help differentiate some of our product IP. The back half of the year was slow as we retooled it. We've actually seen growing into the first half of this year, a nice ramp in the pipeline. And we're starting to see some results of that early on. I do think the first half of 2016 is going to be slower from a growth standpoint. But then when we get to the back half of the year, as that continues to ramp, we'll see Capco to return -- start returning back to more normalized double-digit growth rate for us.

And then you said, I think you said maybe double-digit growth in the back half. Can you give us a sense of the drivers -- and first of all, is that correct? And second of all, give us a sense of the drivers. There were some questions about whether or not there was a systemic sort of industry-wide big bank slowdown in uptake of topic of professional services or whether specific things that were just your business. Can you give us a more color on that?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to be real clear, you hit the nail on the head in the first half of the year. You're going to see flat growth in Capco, maybe even a little bit decline over prior year periods. And then you'll see that ramping up the Moody's point full year give
componenttext: Yes, just to be real clear, you hit the nail on the head in the first half of the year. You're going to see flat growth in Capco, maybe even a little bit decline over prior year periods. And then you'll see that ramping up the Moody's point full year give a mid-single digit and then going into 2017, we do expect Capco to recover it more of that double-digit growth rate. But as you know in the consulting business, that's all about building your pipeline and filling it. And that's in fulfilling -- that's 1 of the things that we changed significantly. What we have done in Capco historically, we've gotten a very large transformational engagement. And we took our eye of the ball of the base business of consulting in my opinion. So we've retooled the leadership there, got them refocused on executing more of these up leadership, consulting engagements. We've seen nice uptick of pipeline. We've actually seen stress come into Q1 with delivery. So we've got to continue that, obviously and continue that growth. But it's going to be much more back to what we picked up in the original Capco acquisition, which is more transformational consulting, where we're doing engagements, more short term in nature around that leadership and how to transform various functions of the financial institution and then allow us to pool in more product IP instead of some of the large lower margin bodyshop type of deployments that we've gotten into. Lance has excellent experience that from his prior life with his former company. He's bringing a great discipline to that's process and we're seeing a lot of improvement early on under his leadership.

componenttextpreview: And I guess first of all, on the IFS segment, it looks like that might have accelerated to around 5% growth if we exclude the gaming business from the prior year. And the strongest growth of the year it looks like. I guess, I'm wondering first of all, if

componenttext: Yes, it's a good comment. I think if you normalize the gaming and the other pieces, we've got about 4.4% growth in the quarter, which we did see as an acceleration. I think, the level of noise in '15 was high compared to '16. '16 should be clean and we see very good line of sight around it. We do have about $8 million of term fees in the quarter that flowed into the IFS group. So that you saw exactly right. We did see some level of acceleration and it's a relatively clean number.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're continuing to see an improvement in retention throughout 2016. As you point out, they've had a very nice slope of improving that over the last several years, and we think that'll continue. Frankly, the conversations with the clients have been e
componenttext: Yes, we're continuing to see an improvement in retention throughout 2016. As you point out, they've had a very nice slope of improving that over the last several years, and we think that'll continue. Frankly, the conversations with the clients have been extremely positive, and I've had an opportunity to have a lot of of those over the last several months. And what we're finding is they're very pleased that FIS was the acquiring company. They're very pleased with how our overall size of relationship has grown through the combination because we would have already a strategic relationship with those clients so makes us that much more scale and so it's all positive. But we are planning for a continued improvement and retention. And we see no evidence that, that won't occur.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to touch on starting off with guidance once again, just as a follow-up. I mean, you came off the year where obviously there were some unforeseen things that have occurred, and so I know the intention hopefully was to come into this year with mor
componenttext: Just want to touch on starting off with guidance once again, just as a follow-up. I mean, you came off the year where obviously there were some unforeseen things that have occurred, and so I know the intention hopefully was to come into this year with more of a conservative guidance assumption. And so here we are with 3% to 4%. Fourth quarter run rate was decent on the IFS segment but obviously like you mentioned for a lot of different reasons slower on the GFS. So when we look going forward, I mean, can you just give us some confidence on if there's anything that would lead to lead guidance being either below that? Or what are those variables? And potentially is that already conservative? Is this sort of the low end of the range inherently what you're giving with upside to that from other variables? I guess some contacts around the conservatism and the nature of our how you really thought about guidance here?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you might imagine coming out of '15 and looking at the macro backdrop, we definitely took a more conservative approach particularly on the revenue growth lines, and specifically on the revenue growth line that are more discretionary in nature. Acr
componenttext: Yes, as you might imagine coming out of '15 and looking at the macro backdrop, we definitely took a more conservative approach particularly on the revenue growth lines, and specifically on the revenue growth line that are more discretionary in nature. Across the board, we think we've got lower sales execution risk in the various clients, and and we've got a larger component of it, the earnings per share growth that what I'll call more controllable about things. Synergies, for example, things that we can go and execute on regardless of macro backdrop. So yes, we think we've got a conservative plan here both in top line and in earnings per share growth into 2016.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good to hear. And then just on the cross-selling side, I'm curious to know, I mean, is there anything included in your outlook around SunGard and what that -- are you seeing any evidence so far of cross-selling in terms of revenue, synergy op
componenttext: Okay, that's good to hear. And then just on the cross-selling side, I'm curious to know, I mean, is there anything included in your outlook around SunGard and what that -- are you seeing any evidence so far of cross-selling in terms of revenue, synergy opportunities, whether it's the wealth business you've talked about in the past or it's Capco or others?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Darrin, I mean,, we were very conservative when we look at cross-selling. But we are, as I've shared in my prepared remarks, we are very excited about what we're seeing in the conversations that are occurring. There are a lot of opportunities as we'r
componenttext: Yes, Darrin, I mean,, we were very conservative when we look at cross-selling. But we are, as I've shared in my prepared remarks, we are very excited about what we're seeing in the conversations that are occurring. There are a lot of opportunities as we're looking at the wealth business and combine it with our existing wealth business and it gives us a substantial scale in that space and allows us to push into the regional community banks and see good progress there. We're seeing great uptick in some of our regions around the world, Europe, Asia and specifically, where we're able to bring our sales resources and SunGard sales resources augmenting with Capco and things from early engagements. So we do think there's going to be some upside. But to Moody's point, we were conservative in our modeling of that.

componenttext: Okay. And just last question for me, when we look at -- when we heard your prepared remarks, you did list off a number of what sounded pretty decent side deals. I mean, I know Bradesco is 1 but also I think you mentioned $100 billion bank for direct banking and some others. Can you give us a little more color on the timing of some of the larger implementations? I mean, Sainsbury sounds like it's in testing mode now and it's going to run through the year, I imagine. Anything else we can just sort of hold on some of the larger deals?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I think you're right. I mean, we've got a lot of large transactions that were signed. The sales team well throughout last year. Frankly, to your point, it does on board over time because of these are big projects and it takes time to get them on
componenttext: Yes, no, I think you're right. I mean, we've got a lot of large transactions that were signed. The sales team well throughout last year. Frankly, to your point, it does on board over time because of these are big projects and it takes time to get them on board. But when you think about Sainsbury, it's going to become the midsummer deployment for what we're calling Phase 2 of that project. The final phase will launch in early '17. So very good progress there. We have high confidence in that and relationship can get better and the things are working very well. We also mentioned U.K. digital bank that will launch in Q2 as well. And then the digital bank that you mentioned, greater than $100 billion, that will drive a lot of services work but that'll be on-boarding throughout '16 and into '17, so that's a little later because we didn't sign that in Q4 and those tend to run about anywhere from 12 to 18 months of deployment time. The Bradesco talk about the large card portfolio, that will also come on in Midsummer.

componenttext: Yes, those are some of the key wins that we've highlighted. Of course, obviously, in the company our size, we've always got a lot of large implementations going on. So we've got to continue to not only execute on our delivery pipeline but also our sales pipeline. We've got to keep building those delivery buckets. And the team been a nice job doing that.

componenttext: Yes, if you look at I think, Ashwin, a couple of things. One, conservative in our revenue growth guidance for '16, first of all. Secondly, as we talked, we do have a broad set of the Payment Solutions business, some of them are growing faster, some of them are growing slower, which is a headwind to overall growth into the IFS group. What we did see was good growth in the banking group and good growth in the business solutions group and EMV card production. So we've got some good growers but we definitely still have some level of headwinds. Again, the macro backdrop here is conservative overall guidance as well.

componenttext: Well, if you think about our check business, for example, check volumes continue to decline and continue to be a headwind overall for us. headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would lean very heavily to debt repayment. In fact, we don't anticipate any share buybacks in 2016. We will close the year out at about 4x leverage. We're targeting to get back down to 2.5x by the end of 2017. But all of our access free cash flow
componenttext: Yes, we would lean very heavily to debt repayment. In fact, we don't anticipate any share buybacks in 2016. We will close the year out at about 4x leverage. We're targeting to get back down to 2.5x by the end of 2017. But all of our access free cash flow will generally be used for word debt paydown, Ashwin, over the course of '16 and through '17 until we delever back with the target level.

So we think that gives us confidence going into '16.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. Turning to Slide 2, Gary Norcross, President and Chief Executive Officer, will begin with a business summary. Woody Woodall, Chief Financial Offic
componenttext:
Thank you, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings call. Turning to Slide 2, Gary Norcross, President and Chief Executive Officer, will begin with a business summary. Woody Woodall, Chief Financial Officer, will continue with the financial results for the quarter and the full year. Today's news release and the supplemental slide presentation are available on our website at fisglobal.com.
Turning to Slide 3. Today's remarks will contain forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described in the press release and other filings with the SEC. The company undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by law. Please refer to the safe harbor language.
Today's remarks will also include references to non-GAAP financial measures in order to provide more meaningful comparisons between the periods presented. These non-GAAP measures are outlined on Slide 3 as well. Reconciliations between the GAAP and non-GAAP results are provided in the attachments to the press release and in the appendix of the supplemental slide presentation.
Turning to Slide 4, I will turn the call over to Gary to discuss the business highlights. Gary?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on today's call. I'm pleased to report that we exited 2015 with solid momentum, as the team's focused on execution and driving further improvements in our cost structure and overall per
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on today's call. I'm pleased to report that we exited 2015 with solid momentum, as the team's focused on execution and driving further improvements in our cost structure and overall performance, delivering continued earnings growth. We're in the right markets empowering our clients of all sizes, whether here in the U.S. with community and regional banks or globally. Our long-term strategy has consistently driven year-over-year performance results, and we remain committed to our strategy. 
Turning to Slide 5. We continue to build global scale in 2015, finalizing our acquisition of SunGard and finishing the year with revenue increasing 7% on a constant currency basis to $6.6 billion, growing adjusted EBITDA 8% on a constant currency basis to $2 billion and producing adjusted earnings per share of 6% on a constant currency basis to $3.22. We generated $921 million free cash flow and returned $605 million to shareholders. Strategically, we are investing in the business to deliver long-term growth and superior shareholder returns. We are entering 2016 focused on 3 growth drivers. First, the acquisition of SunGard broadens our solution portfolio, allowing us to expand into new and adjacent markets and provide deeper value to our clients. Second, we will continue to capitalize on our expanded scale, operating leverage and our disciplined integration to drive earnings growth. Third, our strong cash flow generation allows us to invest for growth and return capital to shareholders. 
Turning to Slide 6. Our SunGard acquisition, which closed on November 30, is a meaningful value creator for FIS. As we have discussed in the past, the industry is continuing to move towards fewer providers due to the complexity of solutions and regulatory oversight. As a result, our strategy has been to continue to expand our broad array of IP-led products built for the financial services industry, augmented with the right transformation services components needed to bridge the gap between these complex systems in the new digital age. The SunGard acquisition is another key component in implementing this overall strategy. In addition to opening complementary new markets, this combination positively impacts our revenue mix, creating a more profitable product-centric revenue base, and the ability to accelerate margin expansion by implementing our leading go-to-market delivery approach as well as significant cost savings around administration and technology expenses. This acquisition expands us beyond our traditional retail banking and payments footprint into the institutional and wholesale side of financial solutions as well as other buy-side organizations. On a combined basis, our share of wallet with our common global clients increased dramatically due to this combination, allowing us to become a more strategic solution provider. This comment has been substantiated multiple times over the last 60 days, as we've engaged with many of our global clients regarding the combination. The benefits of the transaction do not stop with our global banks. It also significantly expands our existing solutions and client base in wealth management, treasury and corporate payments. These are in high demand among our regional and community institutions and has been a significant focus area for FIS, as our clients look for ways to replace their fee revenue due to continuing regulatory change and increased oversight. As we look at the December results for SunGard, we are pleased with the momentum the sales organization maintained throughout the month, and are also pleased with the health of the overall pipeline that we acquired. While still early, we're also excited about how the sales teams are collaborating and building further opportunities within our robust client set, which further substantiates the strategy on why we put these 2 companies together. Finally, this transaction brings very strong talent and increased leadership to FIS with market-specific expertise. This further positions FIS as the clear leader in financial technology globally, strengthening our ability to deliver for our clients and help them grow their business. 
Turning to Slide 7. Based on the significant strategic rationale discussed, the cultural alignment is then equally strong given both companies' DNA is centered on developed products for financial services. This cultural alignment has allowed us to accelerate our integration efforts, and we are very pleased with our initial progress integrating these 2 great companies. For example, we have already rolled out a streamlined organizational structure, transitioned our North American payroll and benefits plans and completed the rollout of the rebranding of SunGard. Given our current pace and results to date, we are ahead of schedule to exit 2016 at our synergy run rate goal of $100 million, and are confident in our ability to exit 2017 with the synergy run rate of $200 million. FIS has a proven track record of meeting or exceeding our synergy targets. And based on progress to date, this record will continue. While that wraps up my comments regarding the strategy and integration of SunGard, the company had other notable successes in support of our growth. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing some of these key results. 
Turn to Slide 8 to review the segment highlights. Our Integrated Financial Solutions business continue to cross-sell and upsell additional products and services through our North American client base, leveraging the strength of our portfolio. In particular, we saw a continued demand for our digital solutions, wealth and card production and institutions of all sizes. In addition, we expanded our relationship with large online retailer in the fourth quarter, resulting in double-digit growth in our high-margin network services business. Our mobile business continues its industry-leading position, growing its number of registered users by 19% year-over-year and delivering 27% year-over-year growth in our hosted service model. Overall, our digital finance, we grew to greater than $250 million in revenues at margins greater than 40%. Card production increased 12% to 112 million cards inclusive of a match for a rise in EMV. EMV grew sequentially 15% from Q3 to Q4 in 2015, resulting in a full year production of 12.5 million EMV cards. We continue to build traction among mid-tier community institutions, signing several new long-term core process and partnerships in the quarter and full year. The success we saw in core processing signings for the year was almost double the number of deals in 2014. These wins in 2015 create positive benefits for 2016 and beyond. Also in the quarter, we signed the bank with assets greater than $200 billion to consolidate its debit processing and associated fraud-related services. The decision was driven by the bank's desire to improve operating efficiencies and increase service flexibility with a common solution across its expansive retail and direct bank business. This significant multiyear agreement demonstrates FIS' strength in serving the payment needs of institutions of all sizes around the world. 2015 was the transition year for Global Financial Solutions business. We responded to the challenges presented to us in the year, whether they were due to global economic issues, overall softness in market demand for people-based services or execution. We made leadership changes to address execution issues and refocused the impacted businesses. Regarding our consulting business, Capco, we're seeing progress in building our pipeline for consultative deals, but continue to expect a slow recovery in the first half of 2016, with increased performance in the back half of the year. As we discussed in the strategic rationale for SunGard, our non-product-led business has now make up less than 10% of our total revenue. Globally, our Clear2Pay business showed very strong momentum, growing over 20% for the full year, fueled by solid demand for real-time payments and a clear competitive differentiation in this space. We acquired Clear2Pay in 2014 with the strategic view of the market's direction, and is another illustration of how disciplined acquisitions and careful integration can enhance our client value proposition and earnings growth profile. During the quarter, our GFS segment signed a bank in North America with assets greater than $100 billion to a new multiyear agreement for a new direct bank, providing an end-to-end integrated solution for core banking, fraud solutions, back office and call center services. This key win underscores our ability to deliver innovative technology solutions that empower our clients to better serve their customers in today's digital age. In Brazil, we were encouraged to see one of our key clients pursue the purchase of a large card portfolio, expanding their franchise for future growth even in a difficult macroeconomic environment. This acquisition expands our ongoing business in Brazil, and we are already seeing the benefit of revenue stream, as we provide professional services expertise to onboard these accounts in the back half of the year. In Europe, we continue to show positive sales momentum, especially in the U.K. and Germany, where we saw important wins across the year, that will fuel continued growth in 2016. Our strategy within the region is building momentum around our expanding relationships by leveraging existing strengths within the FIS and SunGard portfolios. We are making strong progress in the Sainsbury engagement. We have recently delivered the new bank platform, which is a key milestone in the project. Testing is underway, and we now plan to start to migrate customers on to the new platform later this year. We are proud of our partnership with this client, and we look forward to empowering them as our strategic technology partner over the next decade. We also signed the first all-digital bank in the U.K. as we help this client prepare for their upcoming launch in 2016. Asia continue to have strong growth throughout 2015. And we are pleased that the SunGard acquisition more than doubles our sales force in the region, which allows us to continue to address the demand for FIS products and services throughout the high-growth region. 
Turning next to Slide 9. Before I turn the call over to Woody for the financial review, I'd like to summarize by emphasizing that our competitive positioning is strong and our long-term earnings growth story remains intact. To meet our 2016 growth and financial performance goals, we will continue to focus on driving profitable growth, maintaining a strong balance sheet, returning cash to shareholders and continued acceleration of our integration efforts. With that, I'd like to turn it over to Woody for additional detail on our financial results for the quarter and full year. Woody?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. I'll begin with Slide 11 with a summary of our consolidated results for the quarter and then for the full year of 2015. The fourth quarter and full year results included the impact of the SunGard transaction, which closed on November 30. Tho
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. I'll begin with Slide 11 with a summary of our consolidated results for the quarter and then for the full year of 2015. The fourth quarter and full year results included the impact of the SunGard transaction, which closed on November 30. Those results are reported in the GFS segment. Today, unless otherwise specified, I'll be referencing percentage changes in our metrics on a constant currency basis. Also, reconciliations of non-GAAP measures can be found in our press release and our earnings deck, which is posted on the Investor Relations page of our website. In the fourth quarter, revenue increased to $1.9 billion or 18%, and adjusted EBITDA increased 21% to $624 million. Adjusted net earnings from continuing operations increased 13% to $278 million, and adjusted earnings per share was $0.93. In the quarter, foreign currency translation negatively impacted revenue by $63 million, EBITDA by $12 million and earnings per share by $0.02. For the year, revenue increased 7% to $6.6 billion, and adjusted EBITDA increased 8% to $2 billion. Adjusted net earnings from continuing operations increased to $930 million, a 6% increase, and adjusted earnings per share was $3.22. For the year, foreign currency translation negatively impacted revenue by $243 million, EBITDA about $45 million and earnings per share about $0.07. 
I will now continue on Slide 12 for segment results. In the fourth quarter, Integrated Financial Solutions revenue grew 4.4% on a normalized basis to $1 billion. EBITDA was 3% -- EBITDA increased 3% to $405 million compared to the prior-year period. We are pleased with the results of this segment, and the underlying business continues to perform well. For the year, IFS revenue on a normalized basis increased 3% to $3.9 billion, and EBITDA increased 2% to $1.6 billion. 
Turning to Slide 13. Our IFS growth was driven by our digital and risk solutions and by an increase in EMV card production volumes. Recurring revenue composition remains very high in IFS. 
Turning to Slide 14. In the fourth quarter, Global Financial Solutions revenue increased 38% to $902 million. SunGard contributed approximately $300 million of revenue and approximately $100 million of EBITDA. Excluding SunGard on a normalized basis, GFS revenue decreased 3%. This decrease was driven primarily by softness in professional services demand and a difficult comp to the prior-year period. GFS adjusted EBITDA increased to $259 million, representing a 58% increase. EBITDA growth in the quarter was driven by restructuring cost actions taken in the first half of the year and the inclusion of SunGard for 1 month. For the year, GFS revenue increased 16% to $2.7 billion. Excluding SunGard on a normalized basis, revenue grew 3%. EBITDA increased 25% to $629 million. 
Moving to Slide 15. We are presenting the results in the region including SunGard to give some clarity into their regional impacts, although we note that SunGard's impact is only for 1 month. Given that, my following commentary on the regions excludes SunGard and focuses on the GFS segment standalone performance. For the fourth quarter, North America declined approximately $50 million to $252 million. Almost half this decline was a result of the previously discussed contract nonrenewal, followed by continued softness in professional service demand and a difficult license sale comparable in the prior-year period. For the year, North America revenues were $1.1 billion. As with the nonrenewal of the contract, full year revenue decreased 1%, reflecting professional services softness in the second half of the year. In the quarter, Europe grew 1% to $198 million. For the year, Europe revenues increased 14% to $757 million. The fourth quarter results include the anniversary of our Clear2Pay acquisition and the impact of softness for people-based services in Europe. We are pleased about the results in Latin America, and the contract expansion in Brazil is a nice win in the quarter and should help Latin America in 2016 in spite of difficult macroeconomic background. As Gary indicated earlier, we remain bullish on the long-term impact of the Asia Pacific region. The teams have done a nice job of growing the business in this region. The addition of SunGard creates greater contribution from IP-led solutions, which we believe improves the visibility and predictability of results for this segment. 
Moving to Slide 16. For the quarter, free cash flow increased 12% to $399 million or 143% conversion of net earnings. And for the year, free cash flow increased 7% to $921 million or 99% conversion of net earnings. We are highly focused on paying down debt and deleveraging the balance sheet. The effective tax rate increased to 33.4% for the quarter compared to 32.6% in the prior-year period, driven by acquisition-related items. For the full year, the effective tax rate was 33.1%. 
Moving to Slide 17. In 2016 and going forward, we will report revenue growth on an organic basis, organic revenue excluding impact of acquisitions, divestitures and foreign currency translation. We believe this will get better visibility in the underlying operating results of the business. For 2016, we expect organic revenue growth of 3% to 4%; adjusted EBITDA of $2.84 billion to $2.9 billion; adjusted earnings per share of $3.70 to $3.80, representing growth of 15% to 18% free cash flow to approximate adjusted net earnings. As we think about the quarter-to-quarter flow of the operating plan, we generally expect 15% to 18% EPS growth each quarter and expect the impact of synergies and interest savings to increase over the course of the year. There is more information regarding our planning assumptions in the appendix material, but I will highlight a handful of them here. We assumed net interest expense of approximately $370 million and 2016 effective tax rate of approximately 35%. We believe that by implementing tax planning strategies over the next 24 months, we can drive tax rate down by 200 basis points or more, capital expenditures of approximately 6% of revenue, reaffirming our goal of exiting 2016 with $100 million or more in run rate cost synergies. 
Moving to Slide 18. In conclusion, I'm highly confident in our operating plan and our ability to deliver double-digit earnings growth in 2016 and 2017. We remain focused on multiyear earnings growth and cash generation and believe our business model will create long-term shareholder value. And we continue to invest for growth and strive for leadership in the markets that we serve. That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, you may now open the line for questions.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Glad to hear that the SunGard integration is running ahead of plan. Can you provide details around your cost take-out assumptions for SunGard for calendar '16? In other words, what's embedded in the guidance for the full year? And then to the extent you have a target for calendar '17, that would also be helpful.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, again, we're targeting exiting at $100 million or more. I will tell you for planning purposes, I would use the $100 million exit run rate. If you think about the flow of the operating plan, we try to give some color around 15% to 18% each quarter.
componenttext: David, again, we're targeting exiting at $100 million or more. I will tell you for planning purposes, I would use the $100 million exit run rate. If you think about the flow of the operating plan, we try to give some color around 15% to 18% each quarter. If you think about how the synergies will flow, I would lean towards the 15%, moving towards the 18% over the course of the year, as the synergies come through and interest costs are reduced as we pay down debt. For 2017, David, we're still targeting a $200 million exit run rate, and we would have that at least ratable at this point in time.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. David, this is Gary. Obviously, at this point, we're highly confident in achieving that. As I said in my prepared remarks, we compare it to the really last big transaction we did, which was Metavante back in 2009. We're ahead of where we were at this
componenttext: Yes. David, this is Gary. Obviously, at this point, we're highly confident in achieving that. As I said in my prepared remarks, we compare it to the really last big transaction we did, which was Metavante back in 2009. We're ahead of where we were at this point in that process. So we've gone through a number of already very significant milestones with the restructuring, the conversion of payroll and benefits and the other things we mentioned. And now, we've just gotten line of sight into implementing the plans over the course of the year. So we're in really good shape on the integration. It's gone very smoothly at this point.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any color on the demand environment for SunGard? They have a very strong capital market focus and clearly seeing a lot of volatility now in capital markets. Is demand holding up in this environment?
componenttext: Any color on the demand environment for SunGard? They have a very strong capital market focus and clearly seeing a lot of volatility now in capital markets. Is demand holding up in this environment?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was my point I was trying to make in my prepared remarks. I was real pleased with the month of December in our SunGard execution. When I look, they had every opportunity to really take their foot off the gas. I mean, they could have gotten distracted
componenttext: That was my point I was trying to make in my prepared remarks. I was real pleased with the month of December in our SunGard execution. When I look, they had every opportunity to really take their foot off the gas. I mean, they could have gotten distracted with the combination. We had a lot going on at that time, but things stayed very focused through year-end and executed very well. So that was positive. When I look at the pipeline going into this year, the same thing exists. The pipelines are growing. The teams are executing. They're very excited about being a part of FIS, and I think that's translating in the client base. I can't tell you how many comments I've gotten over the last 60 days from clients just talking about being up under FIS, our ability to invest and focus for the long term. And so the customers are receiving it well. Our sales teams are receiving it well, and that's projecting into the results. So we feel really good about it. The secret's going to be, as now since November 30, as we started to put our sales teams together and they've started to have some conversations about joint selling into their account, we're also seeing some good traction there, not only in the global financial Institutions. But as I said, when you look at treasury and wealth and many of the products that SunGard have that are applicable for regional and community banks, we're seeing to see strong traction there as well. And then, of course, as you know, our consulting groups started in the capital markets area of the industry. And so being able to wrap that kind of consultative engagement around products is going to be differentiating for us going forward.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good to hear. And then if you could give a little more color on Capco. You had mentioned, I think, toward the end of last year, Lance Levy would be taking over the business, repositioning it to focus more on high-end transformational consulting. What's th
componenttext: Good to hear. And then if you could give a little more color on Capco. You had mentioned, I think, toward the end of last year, Lance Levy would be taking over the business, repositioning it to focus more on high-end transformational consulting. What's the current growth for Capco? And what do you think it could be exiting '16?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We saw mid-single-digits growth on Capco for the full year last year, which was obviously substantially less than what has been done in the prior years. As you mentioned, Lance is taking over the helm of the consulting group. We've really rallied the
componenttext: Yes. We saw mid-single-digits growth on Capco for the full year last year, which was obviously substantially less than what has been done in the prior years. As you mentioned, Lance is taking over the helm of the consulting group. We've really rallied the partners around engaging more into the transformational consulting side, which drives a higher margin. And also, it's more complementary to help differentiate some of our product IP. The back half of the year was slow as we retooled it. We've actually seen growing into the first half of this year a nice ramp in the pipeline, and we're starting to see some results of that early on. I do think the first half of 2016 is going to be slower from a growth standpoint. But then when we get in the back half of the year, as that continues to ramp, we'll see Capco to return -- start returning back to a more normalized double-digit growth rate for us.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: To be clear, David, the organic 3% to 4% for the consolidated company, we got Capco for the full year in a mid-single-digit zone.
componenttext: To be clear, David, the organic 3% to 4% for the consolidated company, we got Capco for the full year in a mid-single-digit zone.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Got it. And then just 2 quick final housekeeping questions. What FX impact you have built into the 2016 guidance? And then what is your forecast for termination fees?

componenttext: Yes. If you look at the assumption package, there's some details on Slide 20 that's further in there. Right now, we've baked in about a $150 million headwind. That's really driven primarily as a Brazilian real, but still having some headwind in the euro right now. With regard to term fees, we exited 2015 with about $40 million. We've got less than that in 2016. I would tell you probably 20% less.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Brett Huff with Stephens Inc.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more detail on the guidance. I think that we've been trying to figure out, and I think others have been trying to make sure we're understanding the guide. Can you give us a little bit more detail or ballpark on what your SunGard assumpti
componenttext: Just a little bit more detail on the guidance. I think that we've been trying to figure out, and I think others have been trying to make sure we're understanding the guide. Can you give us a little bit more detail or ballpark on what your SunGard assumption is for revenue and maybe even profitability? And I know going forward, there's probably not going to be as much detail. I think we and others are just trying to make sure we're modeling this right here on the first year out. So any help on that would be helpful.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you think about the revenue growth profile, Brett, I would tell you probably in the 3 to 5 zone on the SunGard from the revenue growth standpoint. In terms of margin contribution, our GFS margins without SunGard were about 22% or so. With the syne
componenttext: Yes. If you think about the revenue growth profile, Brett, I would tell you probably in the 3 to 5 zone on the SunGard from the revenue growth standpoint. In terms of margin contribution, our GFS margins without SunGard were about 22% or so. With the synergies, we think the GFS margins grow to 26% plus in 2016. That will continue to grow into 2017 as we get full run rates synergies out of it, but that's what we're looking at in '16 in terms of profitability contribution.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the 22% for the fourth quarter was GFS x SunGard, but the 26% plus is with SunGard and the synergies?
componenttext: Okay. So the 22% for the fourth quarter was GFS x SunGard, but the 26% plus is with SunGard and the synergies?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: To be clear, GFS around 22% would be sort of a full year GFS without SunGard. Adding SunGard and the synergies into 2016, we think the GFS segment growth profile or EBITDA margin profile will be 26% plus.
componenttext: To be clear, GFS around 22% would be sort of a full year GFS without SunGard. Adding SunGard and the synergies into 2016, we think the GFS segment growth profile or EBITDA margin profile will be 26% plus.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. So both of those numbers are for '16? Okay. And then you mentioned specifically, Gary, and I just want to make sure I heard you right, that the slower growth in the Capco portion of consulting, and I'm assuming that's probably the low single-digi
componenttext: Got you. So both of those numbers are for '16? Okay. And then you mentioned specifically, Gary, and I just want to make sure I heard you right, that the slower growth in the Capco portion of consulting, and I'm assuming that's probably the low single-digit range that we've been kind of seeing in the last couple of quarters, and then you said -- I think you said maybe double-digit growth in the back half. Can you give us a sense of the drivers -- first of all, is that correct? And second of all, give us a sense of the drivers. There were some questions about whether or not there was a systemic sort of industry-wide big bank slowdown in uptake of professional services or whether it was some specific things that were just your business. Can you give us some more color on that?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to be real clear, you hit the nail in the head. In the first half of the year, you're going to see flat growth in Capco, maybe even a little declining over prior-year periods. And then you'll see it ramping up, to Woody's point, for the full yea
componenttext: Yes. Just to be real clear, you hit the nail in the head. In the first half of the year, you're going to see flat growth in Capco, maybe even a little declining over prior-year periods. And then you'll see it ramping up, to Woody's point, for the full year getting to a mid-single digit. And then going into 2017, we do expect Capco to recover to more of that double-digit growth rate. But as you know in the consulting business, that's all about building your pipeline and filling it. And that's in fulfilling it. That's one of the things that we changed significantly. What we have done in Capco historically, we've gotten the very large transformational engagements, and we took our eye off the ball of the base business of consulting in my opinion. And so we've retooled the leadership there, got them refocused on executing more of the thought leadership, consulting engagements. We've seen nice uptick of pipeline. We've actually seen strength coming into Q1 with delivery. So we've got to continue that obviously and continue that growth. But it's going to be much more back to what we picked up in the original Capco acquisition, which is more transformational consulting, where we're doing engagements, more short term in nature around thought leadership and how to transform various functions of the financial institution, and then allow us to pool in more product IP instead of some of the large lower-margin body shop-type deployments that we've gotten into. Lance has excellent experience on that from his prior life with his former company. He's bringing a great discipline to that process, and we're seeing a lot of improvement early on under his leadership.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of David Koning from Baird.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, first of all, on the IFS segment, it looks like that might have accelerated to around 5% growth if we exclude the gaming business from the prior year, and the strongest growth of the year it looks like. I guess, I'm wondering first of all if
componenttext: And I guess, first of all, on the IFS segment, it looks like that might have accelerated to around 5% growth if we exclude the gaming business from the prior year, and the strongest growth of the year it looks like. I guess, I'm wondering first of all if that's right. Secondly if there were term fees in the quarter and how much those were in? And then finally, if that higher level of growth is sustainable through 2016?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good comment. I think if you normalize out the gaming and the other pieces, we've got about 4.4% growth in the quarter, which we did see as an acceleration. I think the level of noise in '15 was high compared to '16. '16 should be clean, and w
componenttext: Yes. It's a good comment. I think if you normalize out the gaming and the other pieces, we've got about 4.4% growth in the quarter, which we did see as an acceleration. I think the level of noise in '15 was high compared to '16. '16 should be clean, and we see very good line of sight around it. We did have about $8 million of term fees in the quarter that flowed into the IFS group. So that, you saw it exactly right. We did see some level of acceleration, and it's a relatively clean number.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you are thinking about it right, David, I mean, if the team's done an excellent job of cross-selling and filling in, frankly, as we've described in the past, some of these holes that are created from these clients that are leaving due to being acquire
componenttext: But you are thinking about it right, David, I mean, if the team's done an excellent job of cross-selling and filling in, frankly, as we've described in the past, some of these holes that are created from these clients that are leaving due to being acquired, right? So we saw a nice acceleration of growth, and we're confident about where that's going to come in, in 2016.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, just turning to GFS. You made a lot of comments around SunGard and Capco, but you declined about 3% normalized in Q4. Are we going to turn to growth again in Q1? And maybe if we kind of look through the year, is it low-single-digi
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, just turning to GFS. You made a lot of comments around SunGard and Capco, but you declined about 3% normalized in Q4. Are we going to turn to growth again in Q1? And maybe if we kind of look through the year, is it low-single-digit growth in the first couple of quarters and mid or maybe even a little better in the back half? I just want to know, I guess, if we're just going to grow throughout the year or if Q1 is still a down quarter?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Q1 will not be a down quarter. We will see growth. What you've got is a complement of SunGard continuing to grow the base product or solutions to that business continuing to grow, with Capco having some headwinds still in the first quarter. But yes,
componenttext: Yes. Q1 will not be a down quarter. We will see growth. What you've got is a complement of SunGard continuing to grow the base product or solutions to that business continuing to grow, with Capco having some headwinds still in the first quarter. But yes, we'll see growth and anticipate growth in each quarter.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. SunGard brings an increase in our product-led or product-focused product IP sales, and that group is well. And so those are more sticky in nature. They're also more reoccurring in nature. And so we think that's going to help with the growth throughou
componenttext: Yes. SunGard brings an increase in our product-led or product-focused product IP sales, and that group is well. And so those are more sticky in nature. They're also more reoccurring in nature. And so we think that's going to help with the growth throughout '16.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, just a real quick one on definition. With organic growth through the year, are you going to include SunGard in the prior-year quarter? Or are you going to exclude SunGard from the current quarter as we look through the rest of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And finally, just a real quick one on definition. With organic growth through the year, are you going to include SunGard in the prior-year quarter? Or are you going to exclude SunGard from the current quarter as we look through the rest of the year?

headline: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would include in the prior-year quarter similar to how we have done organic growth in the past. We exclude acquisitions, divestitures and FX very similar to how we did in 2014 and prior.
componenttext: We would include in the prior-year quarter similar to how we have done organic growth in the past. We exclude acquisitions, divestitures and FX very similar to how we did in 2014 and prior.
